title: UBS helps open doors for next generations
text:
UBS dealmaker Kelvin Barry has thrown the firm's weight behind an innovative program that's giving smart school leavers a big break.

As one of UBS Australia’s top dealmakers, Kelvin Barry knows a thing or two about windows of opportunity and multipliers.

Those two concepts are central to the involvement of the firm with Skyline Education Foundation, a Melbourne not-for-profit organisation that helps gifted year 11 and 12 students from disadvantaged backgrounds prepare for life after high school through a two-year program.

On Wednesday, UBS hosted the final masterclass for Skyline’s current intake. The day included sessions on exam preparation, impressing employers and career planning.

Several UBS staff presented, and others called in favours to involve contacts from PwC, Herbert Smith Freehills and A.T Kearney.

Barry says UBS first became involved when it hosted Skyline’s annual reception for alumni and partners.

Several staff made financial donations – it costs about $12,000 to fund one place in the program, which has 30 students – that were later matched by the UBS Foundation. But Barry and his colleagues also found more practical ways to support Skyline’s chief executive, Jane Sydenham-Clarke.
description: UBS dealmaker Kelvin Barry has thrown the firm's weight behind an innovative program that's giving smart school leavers a big break.
